bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, March 31, 1945

div1.p: Hench writes that, due to a translation error, he was under the assumption that he had been appointed to a directorial position at the Finlay Institute. He is very embarrassed about the total affair.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Domingo F. Ramos, March 31, 1945
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
31 March, 1945
His Excellency Doctor Domingo F. Ramos
Director of the Finlay Institute
La Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Ramos:
div1.p:
Recently I had something of a joke pulled on me. In-
advertently, as a result of poor translating on the part of two women
(which just goes to show that I mustn't trust women). I was led to
believe that I had been asked to be a Director. The enclosed corres-
pondence to Doctor Espinosa will explain the situation. I hope indeed
that I have not embarrassed Doctor Espinosa. I am, myself, rather em-
barrassed, but realize that there is only one thing to do and that is
to laugh the whole thing off and hope that you and Doctor Espinosa
don't think too ill of me for having been so stupid about the Spanish
translation. Just to show you why I was led astray, I am enclosing
the actual translation sent to me by Miss Montes.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service Enc.
